Ariane Karla Cruz Gomes

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/1114687625161669
  • Última atualização do currículo em 12/08/2019

Graduada em Ciências Biológicas pela Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (2013) e doutora em Imunologia e Medicina Clínica pela Universidade de Oxford (2019). Atualmente é pesquisadora na Divisão de Infecção e Imunologia na University College London (UK). Tem experiência em imunologia básica e aplicada, desenvolvimento de vacinas baseadas em partículas do tipo viral e modulação terapêutica de receptores do tipo Toll. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2015 - 2018
Innate pattern recognition receptors and IgG class switching ? Implications for vaccine design
Descrição: A universal influenza vaccine has been a long sought goal in the field of vaccines. Here, using an heterologous VLP presenting the highly conserved extracellular domain of the M2 protein from the influenza viruses as an antigen, we demonstrated that the type of the RNA packaged into VLPs can alter the quality of the induced humoral response, namely by modulating isotype switching. We have also provided evidence that the process is predominantly TLR7 dependent, and ruled out a role for MAVS and possibly its upstream sensor RIG-I. Finally, we have evaluated the impact of the quality of humoral responses (i.e. the ratio of different IgG subclasses induced by the vaccine) in the efficacy of the vaccination to protect against influenza-related morbidity in a murine influenza model. Our findings provide further considerations for the rational design of VLP-based vaccines and the immunomodulation exerted by TLR7 ligands packaged within the particles. Based on this work, scientists can be better informed with respect to the impact of manufacturing choices for vaccine production on the induced immune responses and additional variables that can influence the immune response and vaccination outcome..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Ariane Karla Cruz Gomes - Integrante / BACHMANN, MARTIN - Coordenador.
2014 - 2018
Early transcriptional reprograming in dendritic cells and the induction of protective T cell responses upon immunisation with VLPs
Descrição: Inducing T cell responses by therapeutic vaccination requires appropriate activation of antigen presenting cells. The use of virus-like particles (VLPs) containing TLR ligands has demonstrated remarkable potential in modulating the immune response for prophylactic vaccines as well as immunotherapy or prophylactic vaccines. Here, we aimed to employ VLPs associated to TLR ligands as tools to modulate cytotoxic response by CD8+ T cells and provide further insight in the development of T cell-based immunotherapy. We have investigated the transcriptomic profiles in dendritic cells (DCs) from mice immunised with VLPs containing distinct classes of nucleic acid and correlate the expression patterns with the efficiency of T cell responses induced. We identified key pathways activated in DCs that are involved in the appropriated induction of T cell responses and show evidence for the modulatory effect of CCL2 on the CD8+ T cells mediated response. We have also provided evidence for the regulation of IFN-α responses induced by STING upon immunisation with Qβ but not Qβ(CpG) and shown evidence that reduction of expression of CD101 may be a potential mechanism of tumour control by cancer vaccines based on Qβ(CpG). These insights shed light on immune networks that are pivotal for the induction of potent cytotoxic T cell responses and identify key genes for appropriate DC activation and subsequent modulation of the adaptive immune response..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Ariane Karla Cruz Gomes - Integrante / BACHMANN, MARTIN - Coordenador.
2014 - 2016
VLPs as a platform for T cell based vaccine ? Implications of size and mechanism of antigen presentation for vaccine design
Descrição: HPV is the main cause of cervical cancer worldwide. In the recent years, three vaccines have been developed to prevent infection; however, until immunisation programs reach critical coverage in the population, there is still a large part of subjects at risk of developing HPV-related cancer. To those previously infected subjects, a therapeutic vaccine stands as an attractive solution. Here, we investigate the immune response and the characteristics of a therapeutic VLP-based vaccine against HPV-related tumour. The trafficking of antigens from the periphery to lymph nodes (LNs) or spleen is governed mainly by the size of the particles2,3. Nanoparticles within the size range of 20-200nm can freely flow through the lymph rapidly reaching LNs where they can encounter relevant APCs, including DCs and B cells that will initiate the immune responses in addition to encountering effector cells such as CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, that may be engaged in the response depending of the stimuli4. Thus, adjusted size of the particle guarantees the rapid spatial distribution of the antigens to the relevant immune centres, such as LNs. By simply mixing antigens and adjuvants of similar size, it may be possible to target the same individual cells within the LNs avoiding conjugation steps. To test this, we generated particulate adjuvants and antigens of different size and measured humoral and T cell responses. We found that covalent linkage was essential for maximal B cell response regardless of the size of the antigen. In contrast, an admixed formulation of particulate E7 oligomers with CpG-loaded VLPs of similar size was sufficient to induce optimal CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses that proved to be protective as a therapeutic vaccine in an HPV tumour model. These findings have direct implications for vaccine design and can be employed to further understand the requirements for induction of appropriate T and B cell responses upon vaccination. Published: Gomes, AC et al / Frontiers in Immunology, 8(March), 1?10.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Ariane Karla Cruz Gomes - Integrante / Martin F. Bachmann - Coordenador / Aadil El-Turabi - Integrante.
2011 - Atual
Papel da Bradicinina na inflamação e fibrose pulmonar induzida por bleomicina em animais deficientes para os receptores B1R e B2R ou tratados com antagonistas
Descrição: Estudo do papel da Bradicinina na inflamação e fibrose pulmonar induzida por bleomicina em animais deficientes para os receptores B1R e B2R ou tratados com antagonistas.
Situação: Desativado; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (3) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Ariane Karla Cruz Gomes - Integrante / remo de castro russo - Coordenador.
2011 - Atual
Deficiency of the decoy receptor D6 protects mice from lethality induced by Influenza A(IAV) infection
Descrição: Influenza A virus (IAV) infection has major relevance in worldwide epidemic episodes causing several cases of respiratory diseases and the severe pandemic H1N1. Once infected, the immune response is recruited to overcome pathogen proliferation, but in many cases an unbalanced immune response is responsible for intense tissue damage sometimes worse than the infection itself. The scavenger receptor D6, a seven transmembrane receptor that selectively bind and targets β-chemokines (CC motif) for degradation, is constantly reported as a pro-resolutive receptor with protective role on many diseases by reducing the concentration of inflammatory mediators. The role of D6 receptor is evaluated in IAV infection and our findings demonstrate an atypical effect of D6 depletion, which resulted in protective effect..
Situação: Desativado; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (3) / Doutorado: (4) .

Integrantes: Ariane Karla Cruz Gomes - Integrante / RUSSO, REMO C - Coordenador / TEIXEIRA, MAURO M - Integrante / Cristiana Couto Garcia - Integrante.
